title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 1 august [1867]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 1 August [1867]
text: 1867August 1my dear Walti will try once more to write A line to say we are all about the same only the hot weather is disappearddisappeared in some measure it was bad enoughfenough here we had awfullawful bad smells mr hambler said it came from the privy sprivies in pacific stPacific St. the yards in that street backs up to ours but they are very or quite respectable houses he said he had complained to the board of health but whitherwhether they have done any thing or not we dontdon't smell it to day) the sewer i believe is not in that street there is a water closet in this yard when we came here it was all out of order didentdidn't work at all I told the man I wished he would have it fixed but he didentdidn't doodo it then i told the landlady it made me sick every time i went in so after a while he went to work and fixed it they are so fraidafraid of laying out one cent and want such A high rent I paid him the rent last night that makes fifty dolldollars since we have been) here we pay in advance i told george 300 dolrsdollars A year would help on a house itsit's too much rent but we couldentcouldn't doodo no better then if we only had one more room or the bedrooms were any size but they are so small the rooms is very deep but not very wide they are 40 feet deep i got so many envelopes i shall have to write whether imi'm lame or not they all come safe Walt and i was glad to have them it is so handy to have in the hand the money and the package all come yesterday i think this letter carrier is very correct i dontdon't know whatswhat's the matter with matt i haventhaven't had a letter from her in quite a long time i expected one yesterday to be shuresure i got one from mary it was for matty but it was directed mrs Whitman city hall care of mr lane so they sent it here she was to portsmouthPortsmouth when she wrote but was coming home and wrote for matt to come to greenportGreenport but i gessguess mat wontwon't go this summer) Edd went down and found where nancy lived yesterday she moved in the same st they are all fat edd says and dirty but grow any how he said the house looked better than formerly i was glad to hear from them i have thought about them often this hot weather i feel to sympathisesympathize with mr OconorMr. O'Connor in his getting a house i think itsit's about the worst and most disagreabledisagreeable fix any one can be in Walt doodo you know i like his writings the good gray poet better than i doo borroughs book OconersO'Connor's shows the spirit its wrote in i should form an idea of the man if i had never seen him by reading his writing i suppose you see that peicepiece in the sundaySunday timesTimes as you didentdidn't say any thing about it i will send it i wish septemberSeptember would hurry up so you could come we will make out for room so come as soon as you can) george is pretty well now good bie walter Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 1 August [1867]
